Problem:
Consider a system governed by a complex function \(\{ z(t) \}\) that maps complex numbers onto a complex plane. The function is defined by \( z(t) = e^{i\omega t}z_0 \), where \( \omega \) is a real constant and \( z_0 \) is the initial complex number. We explore the effects of the transformation \( f(z) = e^{\alpha t}z \) where \( \alpha \) is another real constant, on the evolution of this system.

If \( f(z) \) is applied to a complex number \( z_0 \) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \( z(t) = e^{i \omega t}z_0 \) without further intervention, will \( z(T) \) at t = T be the same as if \( z_0 \) was directly evolved to t = T under \( z(t) = e^{i \omega t}z_0 \)?
Explanation: Applying \( f(z) \) initially changes the magnitude of \( z_0 \) by a factor of \( e^{\alpha T} \), thus altering its trajectory in the complex plane. This change in magnitude causes \( z(T) \) to differ from what would be obtained by simply evolving \( z_0 \) under \( z(t) = e^{i \omega t}z_0 \).
